data.author: Apaar Sharma
data.content: A 36-year-old man in Italy has tested positive for COVID-19, monkeypox, and HIV at the same time after returning from a trip in Spain where he engaged in unprotected sex, according to researchers from the University of Catania. This is the first known case of a person testing positive for the three viruses at the same time.
data.title: Italian man tests positive for COVID-19, monkeypox & HIV at the same time

data.author: Apaar Sharma
data.content: Centre has issued an advisory to states on Hand, Foot and Mouth Disease or Tomato Flu. It is a self-limiting illness mostly targeting young children aged 1-10 years and immunocompromised adults with no specific drug to treat it. The virus is not related to SARS-CoV-2, monkeypox, dengue or chikungunya. Best prevention is maintenance of proper hygiene and sanitisation of surroundings.
data.title: Centre issues advisory to states on Tomato Flu

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Often referred to as the 'red planet', Mars is not entirely red, NASA's Perseverance Rover has found. As it arrived at Mars' Jezero crater, it spotted volcanic rocks that are green, scientists said. These rocks are composed of "large grains of olivine, the muddier less-gemlike version of peridot that tints so many of Hawaii's beaches dark green", NASA stated.
data.title: Mars is not entirely red: NASA

data.author: Hiral Goyal
data.content: The NASA is set to launch Artemis 1 on August 29, the first mission in its lunar programme which aims to land astronauts on the Moon in 2025. The mission marks the debut of the most powerful rocket ever, which will send the Orion capsule on a 42-day journey around the Moon. The capsule won't carry any astronauts on board.
data.title: What is Artemis 1, NASA's uncrewed Moon mission to be launched on Aug 29?

data.author: Anmol Sharma
data.content: A huge sunspot on the Sun's surface has grown 10 times in size in the last 48 hours. The sunspot, called AR3085, is also shooting off several minor solar flares. Sunspots are areas that appear dark on the surface of the Sun. They appear dark because they are cooler than other parts of the Sun's surface, as per NASA.
data.title: Huge sunspot on Sun's surface grows 10 times in size in 48 hours, pic surfaces

data.author: Sakshita Khosla
data.content: NASA has said its Perseverance Rover has found that the floor of the Jezero Crater is made up of "rocks that have interacted with water". Scientists had expected to find sedimentary rocks at bottom of the Crater which held a lake billions of years ago, NASA said. But instead, they found two types of igneous rocks, it added.
data.title: NASA's Rover finds 'rocks shaped by water' on Mars

data.author: Ankush Verma
data.content: A huge dinosaur skeleton has been uncovered in a man's back garden in Portugal. Portuguese and Spanish palaeontologists excavated the dinosaur in August and believe it is a sauropod, which were herbivorous, four-legged creatures who had long necks and tails. The remains are now being studied by an international research team.
data.title: Huge dinosaur skeleton discovered in man's back garden in Portugal; pics viral

data.author: Anmol Sharma
data.content: Previously submerged dinosaur footprints have been uncovered in US' Texas after a river dried up due to a drought. A representative of the Dinosaur Valley State Park said that the footprints belonged to an Acrocanthosaurus, a relative of the Tyrannosaurus Rex that stood 15 feet high. The tracks are believed to have been left around 113 million years ago.
data.title: Footprints of dinosaur from 113 million years ago spotted in US, pic surfaces

data.author: Sakshita Khosla
data.content: The world's most powerful telescope, NASA's James Webb Space Telescope, has taken two new pictures of Jupiter, which captured its auroras and rings in detail. The pictures show Jupiter with its rings which are "a million times fainter than the planet" as well as two tiny moons, ESA said. Galaxies are seen "photobombing" Jupiter in a picture, it added.
data.title: Jupiter's auroras seen in detail in new pics from world's most powerful telescope

data.author: Anmol Sharma
data.content: Astronaut Samantha Cristoforetti took to Twitter to share a picture of a "bright dot" on Earth as seen from the space. She wrote, "Intriguing sight! A bright dot in the Negev desert...so unusual to see human-made lights in day passes!" She added, "It's a concentrated solar power plant, one of the technologies to get renewable energy from the Sun."
data.title: Astronaut shares pic of 'bright dot' on Earth as seen from space

data.author: Daisy Mowke
data.content: Researchers from University of Cambridge created model embryos from mouse stem cells that form a brain and beating heart. The team developed the embryo model without eggs or sperm, and instead used stem cells. Researchers mimicked natural processes in lab by guiding the three types of stem cells found in early mammalian development to the point where they start interacting.
data.title: 'Synthetic' embryo with brain and beating heart grown without eggs or sperm

data.author: Aishwarya Awasthi
data.content: SpaceX successfully launched 54 Starlink satellites to orbit on Saturday marking its 38th mission of 2022. It was reportedly also the 24th mission of the year devoted to Starlink. The satellites were launched from Cape Canaveral Space Force Station in Florida atop a two-stage Falcon 9 rocket. The launch comes right ahead of NASA's Artemis l launch on August 29.
data.title: SpaceX launches 54 Starlink satellites in 38th mission this year

data.author: Aishwarya Awasthi
data.content: An uncrewed SpaceX Dragon cargo spacecraft has returned from the International Space Station with over 4,000 pounds of valuable scientific experiments and other cargo. With this, SpaceX completed its 25th cargo resupply mission to the space station. SpaceX launched the mission in July and delivered 5,800 pounds of science experiments, crew supplies and other critical cargo.
data.title: SpaceX Dragon spacecraft returns from ISS with 4,000 pounds of cargo

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: A 100-foot-wide asteroid is expected to pass past the Earth on August 28, NASA said. There's, however, a chance that the asteroid might deviate from its path and move towards the Earth due to its gravitational pull. In case, it strikes the planet, it would not only flatten tens of kilometres of land but would also cause earthquakes and tsunamis.
data.title: A 100-foot-wide asteroid heading towards Earth: NASA

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Rocket Lab is planning to launch the first private mission to Venus to probe the signs of life on the planet. The California-based company is building a spacecraft to fly through the planet's upper atmosphere, almost 30 miles above its surface, for roughly five minutes. The mission will be carried out using Electron Launch Vehicle and a Photon spacecraft.
data.title: Rocket Lab to send first private spacecraft to Venus to find signs of life

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: A battered fossil leg bone of an ancient human relative discovered near the famous Toumai skull in 2001 in Chad suggests that the human lineage was possibly walking upright seven million years ago. The position of its vertebral column suggests that the species called Sahelanthropus tchadensis walked on two feet. They also sometimes moved through the trees, a researcher said.
data.title: Human ancestors walked upright 7 mn years ago, ancient limb bone suggests

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: A study published in the journal Royal Society Open Science has claimed that the Dugong, has gone functionally extinct in China. Researchers conducted several interviews in fishing communities across the country for the study. The Dugong, also known as the 'sea cow', is similar to the American manatee and can grow to about 3.4 metres in length.
data.title: Dugongs functionally extinct in China: Study

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: The Swiss Alps have lost nearly 50% of their glaciers in the last 80 years, a study has found. The scientists used images from the early 20th century to quantify how the climate crisis has impacted the mountains over the past eight decades. On average, the Alps have lost 0.73 cubic kilometres of ice per year, the researchers have found.
data.title: The Swiss Alps have lost 50% of their glaciers in 80 years: Study

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: NASA's TESS space telescope has discovered a 'Water World' exoplanet nearly 100 light-years away from Earth. Named TOI-1452b, the exoplanet that orbits a star four times smaller than Sun was discovered two years ago and is covered in deep oceans. "We've to see if that much water can survive for...long time on planets in...habitable zone," a researcher said.
data.title: NASA finds 'Water World' exoplanet 100 light-years away from Earth

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Researchers from Banaras Hindu University have discovered a new genus of cyanobacteria in Tripura. While the newly-discovered genus has been named Johanseniella, after well-known phycologist Professor Jeffrey R Johansen, the species has been named Tripurensis as it was discovered in Tripura. Researchers believe there might be numerous cyanobacteria in the Northeast that are yet to be discovered.
data.title: BHU researchers discover new genus of cyanobacteria in Tripura

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Fossils of a new species of the giant sea lizard mosasaur that lived around 66 million years ago have been discovered in Morocco. Named Thalassotitan atrox, the species grew up to 9 m in length and was a distant relative of modern iguanas and monitor lizards. It had massive jaws and teeth and hunted other marine reptiles, including sea turtles.
data.title: Fossils of giant sea lizard that lived 66 mn yrs ago discovered in Morocco

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: NASA's James Webb Space Telescope has captured the first clear evidence for CO2 in the atmosphere of an exoplanet. The gas giant planet named WASP-39 b orbits a Sun-like star 700 light-years away from the Earth. "Detecting such a clear signal of carbon dioxide on WASP-39 b bodes well for...detection of atmospheres on smaller, terrestrial-sized planets," a researcher said.
data.title: In a first, NASA's James Webb Space Telescope detects CO2 on exoplanet

data.author: Purnima Rajput
data.content: A report by the European Commission's science and knowledge service, the Joint Research Centre, shows that nearly two-thirds of Europe is threatened by drought. The drought may be the worst in "at least 500 years", Johannes Bahrke, European Commission spokesperson, said. The report mentioned that 47% of Europe is under warning conditions with a soil moisture deficit.
data.title: Europe is facing its worst drought in 500 years: Report

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Scientists have developed a seasoning from mealworms that could be a "healthy" alternative to meat. As per researchers, the worms, when cooked, have similar genetic compounds to ones formed in meat and seafood and could have a 'meat-like', savoury taste. "Insects are...nutritious...with high amounts of fatty acids, vitamins... fibre and...protein, which is like, that of meat," a researcher said.
data.title: Scientists develop ‘healthy’ seasoning from mealworms to replace meat

data.author: Swati Dubey
data.content: Researchers from the University of Cambridge have developed ultra-thin and flexible artificial leaves that generate clean fuels using sunlight and water. Inspired by the process of photosynthesis, these leaves can split water into hydrogen and oxygen or reduce carbon dioxide to syngas or synthetic gas, a mixture of carbon monoxide and hydrogen that can be used as fuel.
data.title: Researchers develop artificial leaves that produce clean fuel from sunlight
